items.description: Tidal River Avon at Bristol, Pill and Shirehampton

floodArea.county: City of Bristol, North Somerset, South Gloucestershire

items.message: Flood alert issued as a result of high spring tides. Forecast high water is at 20:30 on Saturday 10/09/22 with a level of 7.42 mAOD with force 2 South Easterly wind. All times are local and refer to the high water time at Avonmouth. mAOD is height above average sea level, for more detail refer to local tide tables. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply one to two hours either side of the high tide.  We expect flooding to affect the tidal River Avon from Sea Mills to Conham in Bristol and between the Avonmouth Bridge and Shirehampton Park including Pill and Shirehampton.  There will be further high tides from Sunday evening 11/09/22 until Monday evening 12/09/22 so this alert will remain in place until then. We are closely monitoring the situation.   Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and be careful along promenades, coastal footpaths and roads. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Sunday, 11/09/22, or as the situation changes.

Flood alert issued as a result of high spring tides. Tides will be high between 19:30 and 21:30 this evening 10/09/22. Flooding to roads and farmland is possible at these times, however conditions may apply two to four hours either side of the high tide.  Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the Wye Estuary from Redbrook to Chepstow. 
Predicted peaks:- Avonmouth Portbury 7.4m to 7.7m at 20:30 this evening 10/09/22, and 7.2m to 7.5m at 8:45 tomorrow morning 11/09/22, Newport 7.0m to 7.3m at 20:15 this evening 10/09/22, and 6.9m to 7.2m at 8:45 tomorrow morning 11/09/22. 
A series of high tides is due over the next 3 days.  The highest tides are forecast for Sunday and Monday evening.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please be careful along promenades, coastal footpaths and roads.
Please call 999 if in immediate danger.  
This message will be updated  by 01:00 on 11/09/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels are expected to be higher than usual at Fiddlers Ferry, Eastford Road, and Arpley Bridge as a result of a high tide tomorrow morning (11/09/22). Consequently, flooding of low lying land, roads and farmland is expected between 1:00 am and 2:15am on 11/09/22 in the following places: Fiddlers Ferry, between 1:00 and 1:30, Eastford Road, between 1:30 and 2:00 am, Arpley Bridge, between 1:45 and 2:15 am. It is possible that river levels may affect Arpley Road under the railway bridge. Flood alerts may also be required for subsequent high tides. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue flood warnings if necessary. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated tomorrow.

items.description: Wyre estuary from Fleetwood and Knott End to Little Eccleston
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been issued due to the high tide forecast at 23:15 on Saturday 10/09/2022.

Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected between 22:30 and midnight on Saturday 10/09/2022.

No flooding of properties is expected.

Avoid footpaths along the coastline and estuary. Take care planning driving routes to coastal roads, which may be flooded.

Further flood alerts may be issued as part of this high spring tide cycle which lasts until Tuesday 13/09/2022.

This message will be updated by 10:00 AM on 11/09/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.67 mAOD at 04:15 on 11/09/22.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is low for this time of year at 14 cubic metres per second and is falling. We anticipate the flows to remain low for the next 5 days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 10:00 on 11/09/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:00pm today, Saturday 10th September, and 1:00am tomorrow, Sunday 11th September. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea seafront may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.70mAODN at midnight tonight, Saturday 10th September, which is 0.19m above tide tables, wind force 4, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Sunday 11th September.

items.description: The Suffolk and Essex coast from Felixstowe to Clacton including Orwell and Stour estuaries

floodArea.riverOrSea: North Sea, River Orwell, River Deben

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:00pm today, Saturday 10th September, and 1:00am tomorrow, Sunday 11th September. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. The flood gates at Felixstowe seafront will be closed. The waterfront at Pin Mill, and The Strand at Wherstead under the Orwell Bridge may be flooded. Water may be on the quay at Mistley. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.50mAODN at midnight tonight, Saturday 10th September, which is 0.23m above tide tables, wind force 4, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Sunday 11th September.

This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:00pm today, Saturday 10th September, and 1:00am tomorrow, Sunday 11th September. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.50mAODN at midnight tonight, Saturday 10th September, which is 0.23m above tide tables, wind force 4, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Sunday 11th September.

As a result of high spring tides, tides will be high overnight on 10/09/2022. The tides will peak around midnight but will be high for a couple of hours either side.
Areas most at risk include Coast at North Morecambe Bay from Roosebeck to Carnforth including low lying areas around Ulverston, Greenodd, Haverthwaite, Flookburgh, Grange-over-Sands, Levens, Milnthorpe, Sandside, Arnside and Silverdale. No property flooding is expected. We are closing locks and flood gates in the area.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by Sunday afternoon, 11/09/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
Coastal conditions should ease for the high tide today, 10/09/22. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.

items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. The risk of the heaviest rainfall has now passed, and we do not expect there to be any further risk of flooding from rivers in the area at this time.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort and surrounding marshland
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 10:45pm today, Saturday 10th September, and 2:45am tomorrow, Sunday 11th September. Tides are expected to be higher than usual, due to the forecast weather conditions during spring tides. Areas most at risk are Coalhouse Fort and car park, and the low lying land between the fort and Coalhouse Point. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.41mAODN overnight at 12:45am, Sunday 11th September, which is 0.23m above tide tables, wind force 2, northerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 10:30am tomorrow, Sunday 11th September.
